body: Need to figure this out before release... @eickenberg, @louity?

> If method='standard', the output is of shape (B, 2*M*N*O, total_scales, L+1), where total_scales is the number of scales at all orders, that is (J+1)+J*(J+1)/2 if order_2=True.

üò± üò± ‚ùóÔ∏è ‚ùóÔ∏è ‚ùóÔ∏è 

Why do we ravel space and not keep it like every other part of this software package?

> These zeroes should probably be eliminated.

yeah

> where integral_powers is the argument provided to forward()
üëé 

> where points is the argument provided to forward()

maybe OK.

> 'integral' and 'local' can be computed from 'standard', but this may not be computationally optimal.

indeed, though I do not know whether the code actually does anything to optimize. But I think these possibilities should be kept because 3D can easily fill up GPU memory.

> I suggest that we adopt a similar output shape (B, C, M, N, O), where the second axis comingles orders, scales, ells, integral powers, and points, as the case may be.

yeah I agree

> Alternatively, for 'integral' and 'local', the third axis could index integral_powers or points instead of a singleton spatial dimension.

yeah why not


I agree that this needs to be addressed.

> Why do we ravel space and not keep it like every other part of this software package?

:man_shrugging: 
 
> > These zeroes should probably be eliminated.
> 
> yeah

I'm glad we agree on this.
 
> > where integral_powers is the argument provided to forward()
>
> -1

So make this an attribute? This is what #230 suggests.
 
> > where points is the argument provided to forward()
> 
> maybe OK.

Again, #230 is the place to discuss this. For consistency, I'd prefer no arguments to `forward` except for the array.

> > 'integral' and 'local' can be computed from 'standard', but this may not be computationally optimal.
> 
> indeed, though I do not know whether the code actually does anything to optimize. But I think these possibilities should be kept because 3D can easily fill up GPU memory.

Well, you skip a lowpass filter in `integral` and I think `local` replaces that lowpass convolution with an inner product, so those should be non-trivial speedups.

> > I suggest that we adopt a similar output shape (B, C, M, N, O), where the second axis comingles orders, scales, ells, integral powers, and points, as the case may be.
> 
> yeah I agree

Ok good.

> 
> > Alternatively, for 'integral' and 'local', the third axis could index integral_powers or points instead of a singleton spatial dimension.
> 
> yeah why not

Good.

> I agree that this needs to be addressed.

Ok. So if I've understood correctly, this is the plan:

- Remove extraneous zeros in `standard`.
- Do not ravel space in `standard`.
- Make third axis index `integral_powers` (for `integral`) or `points` (for `local`).
- (Remove kwargs and put them as attributes, but again, this is #230)

Does that sound correct?

while we're at it, i should add that I don't find the kwarg name `method` to be informative enough. I had this discussion with @eickenberg last month. Him and I came up with the name `sampling` as a replacement for `method`.

> while we're at it, i should add that I don't find the kwarg name `method` to be informative enough. I had this discussion with @eickenberg last month. Him and I came up with the name `sampling` as a replacement for `method`.

Ok. Can you make a separate issue?

issue.title: [RFC] `method` kwarg is not descriptive enough

repository.name: kymatio
repository.description: Wavelet scattering transforms in Python with GPU acceleration

issue.body:
This came in discussion over Slack and resurfaced in #222
I would be in favor of renaming the `method` kwarg in `Scattering3D` to something more descriptive, like `sampling`.
Below is a discussion I've have with @eickenberg 3 weeks ago on the topic. You will see that, at first, I'm in favor of the term `averaging`, and then I change my mind to `sampling`.


> lostanlen [21 days ago]
> I would be in favor of renaming the `method` kward in scattering3d, into `averaging`
> so that `standard`, `integral`, and `local`
> would rename to
> `local`, `global`, and `foveal` respectively
> this distinction is also very useful in 1d and 2d, so it could be added in the future without API break
> `points` could be renamed to `foveal_coords` for clarity but that‚Äôs a small change that does not require a cross-module deprecation (edited)


Michael [21 days ago]
I agree with all of that except the word foveal - not sure that is the right term, but maybe I also don't completely understand the concept

> lostanlen [21 days ago]
> this is something on which @Mathieu has more expertise, but it‚Äôs basically the scattering transform 
> of x(t) computed only at t=0 (or at a small, finite number of points) rather than at every t
> so that spares the convolution with phi for going from U to S, which considerably speeds up the code
> this is super useful in time series forecasting. also when you don‚Äôt need invariance to translation because the object is already registered around a natural ‚Äúcenter‚Äù for you.
> see paper by Chang, Mallat, and Yap in Applied and Computational Harmonic Analysis. It‚Äôs brilliant 
> `foveated` might be preferable over `foveal`. `foveated` is computer vision terminology whereas `foveal` relates more to anatomy

Michael [21 days ago]
Oh yeah I know that paper -- I just didn't see a connection to the 3d option of evaluation in specific points, since these need not be foveal points

> lostanlen [21 days ago]
> why not? aren‚Äôt they foveal points by virtue of being ‚Äúspecific‚Äù (i.e. user-defined)?

Michael [21 days ago]
To me a fovea is a point of concentration of measurements, not just a specific choice of measurements
given a certain budget of measurements but which you get to apply anywhere, for some signals and tasks it is beneficial to concentrate them
e.g. https://bair.berkeley.edu/blog/2017/11/09/learn-to-attend-fovea/
The Berkeley Artificial Intelligence Research Blog
The Emergence of a Fovea while Learning to Attend
The BAIR Blog (135 kB)

> lostanlen [21 days ago]
> ok, so that is necessarily an adaptive thing?
> hm

Michael [21 days ago]
not adaptive necessarily, but concentrating measurements

> lostanlen [21 days ago]
> perhaps `averaging=None` would make the most sense then? (edited)
> well no because that could imply that we return the whole `U` for every `t`, not just near one point `t=0` 

Michael [21 days ago]
i.e. specifying a regular grid of measurements is not foveating, and one can do that in the 3d case. so i don't think it's about foveating but rather just evaluating wherever one wants
but again, I don't even understand what this was implemented for. If it was implemented with foveation in mind, then maybe it's legit to call it that
So I would definitely like to see an `averaging=None` option for returning U, but the evaluation in specific points thing seems to be different from that

> lostanlen [21 days ago]
> right.
> ... and I thought `averaging='foveal'` was clever :/
> I have an idea. It‚Äôs good and bad at the same time
> `averaging=x` where the array-like variable `x` contains the point(s) around which we measure the scattering transform
> then `sampling` would be a better term than `averaging`
> (and that could generalize beyond averages, like `ell_p` pooling for instance)
> so `sampling='local'` (default), `sampling='global'` (aka `integral`), `sampling=x` (return U at specific values), `sampling=None` (return U entirely, but that‚Äôs out of the scope of 0.1) (edited)


Michael [21 days ago]
is `local` low-passed or how is it different from `None` ?
I like the idea in general

> lostanlen [21 days ago]
> yeah, `local` is low-passed

Michael [21 days ago]
more generally I guess it is an "output transform"
(at the implementation level)

> lostanlen [21 days ago]
> right. but this matters a lot because Kymatio is depth-first to minimize the memory overhead

Michael [21 days ago]
`sampling` seems like a good word for it

> lostanlen [21 days ago]
> so we can‚Äôt guarantee that U2 will fit into memory (especially in GPU memory). therefore we ‚Äúsample‚Äù (average, pool, sum, cherry-pick values, whatever) each path before computing the next one

issue.title: REF Homogenize 3d output

repository.name: kymatio
repository.description: Wavelet scattering transforms in Python with GPU acceleration

issue.body:
This doesn't work yet. I have refactored the `standard` output so that it doesn't ravel, but my brain is in a state where I can't get the test data reshaped correctly to make the test pass.

This is the last thing we need to fix before being able to release

[EDIT by @lostanlen: closes #222]
